EDITORIAL.
If

0;9

HE NEWS-LETTER wishes to express its thanks to the Board of
Editors of the 1907 Hullabaloo for the kind loan of the photographs
which are published in this issue. In regard to the individual plates
the NEWS-LETTER regrets the impossibility of presenting the photographs of every member of the Senior class; and has, therefore,
picked out several men, not necessarily better than the other members
of their class, but representative of the class. Hopkins must realize
how much they loose by the graduation of the class of 1907. As
undergraduates they have done much for the University; as gradv is le
uates, "Medies" and Alumni they are able, if they will, to do even
more. Good luck to them, every one!

4R.

:$:$:

ITH this issue the eleventh volume of the NEWS-LETTER is brought
to an end. The first nUmber of the volume was published while
Little Ross street was echoing with the squeals of the infant class of
1909; this final number will come into the hands of its readers after
the new freshmen have received their first lessons in the art of conducting themselves properly.
The NEWS-LETTER has partaken in the joys and sorrows of the
past year at Hopkins. The not over-brilliant showing made by the
Football team last fall has been more than offset by the splendid work
of the Lacrosse team this spring, the defeat (which by the way was
nearly a victory) at the Annapolis meet was atoned for by the victory over Virginia. And so
it is always in life. Even the NEWS-LETTER has had like experiences—but in spite of the
mental defeats of the Board of Editors when vainly trying to think up a new joke, we too
have our victories—of which the promise of another successful year next winter is a notable
one.

(.-If/eI. Poe.)

Dearest, thy voice comes to me,
To-night as to a wave-beat shore,
The song of sailors, far at sea,
Echoes the stormy ocean o'er,
And then is heard no more.

4

To hold that little hand of thine,
Fain would I now, to feel that hand,
All powerful though held in mine,
Yet holding me by stronger band
Than ever moored a ship to land.
Dearest I see thy face to-night,
So pure, so fragrant, and so fair;•
Before me in the dimness bright,
As bright as truth, I see thee there,
Yet gaze but on the vacant air!
If in my visions thus thou art,
Small wonder then, that I love thee;
The shadow is a tiny part
Of thy real beauty, and to see
Thyself is heaven of heaven to me!

CUPID'S STRATAGEM.

had

For once in her life Elizabeth Winter was
his

and she with equal determination bad

that he should not speak that night.
realized that in her girlish caprice she had not

oily the memory of the suffering on his face,

expression which first told her what her "After all," he thought, "what reason have I

young people talking and laughing merrily as me; she shall never grieve beeause I suffer,
since she cannot love me." He bade her
they passed.
good-night somewhat abruptly, and, little
Elizabeth turned mechanically, went into
knowing how in one lingering look he had
the house, locked the door behind her, and,
told the girl his whole heart's story, he left her
going to her own room, threw herself into a
stunned and awed by the strength of the feelchair, and proceeded to think matters over
ing which she had read in that one moment.
calmly, or, at lesst quietly.
It was nearly daylight before Elizabeth
She had known Harry Gaylord for more found relief in sleep. The thought that she
than two years, and, tho' the friendship which could atone for her folly when she next saw
had existed between them from the beginning Harry seemed to bring little comfort. Next
of their acquaintance had been very pleasant time seemed so vague and far-off. When she
and matter-of-fact, her woman's intuition had awoke, after a few hours of troubled sleep, it
told her sometime since that she was becom- was with a dull sense of present or impending
ing more to him than could be expressed in calamity. She dressed and went down to the
the word "friend." She did not question her breakfast-room, but none of the other memown heart, but was quite content to let mat- bers of the family had yet made their appearters rest as they were. She acknowledged the ance. The morning paper lay beside her
congeniality between him and herself and father's plate, and, as she picked it up and
recognized the full value of the sterling glanced carelessly over it, her eye fell upon
qualities which he possessed, but her heart the following notice: Died—"Of heart-failure,
was in no hurry to own the master, and she on July 20th, Henry Gaylord at 362 Nelson
chatted and danced with other men, often Street."
finding compensation for the lack of pleasure
Putting the paper back in its place she
which she found in their company in her returned to her room, hardly comprehending
mischievous enjoyment of the look of annoy- the meaning of what she had read. There
ance on Harry's face.
could be no doubt about it—"Henry Gaylord
On the evening in question there had been at 362 Nelson Street;" his name was probably
something in Harry Gaylord's manner when Henry, altho she had always kuown him as

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Harry, and the address given was certainly
his. Then like a flash she remembered how,
on the preceding evening, he had suddenly
turned pale and stopped in the middle of a
sentence, but had assured her that it was only
a sharp pain around the heart which the
Doctor said was nothing serious—and now,
he was gone ! gone, before she could tell him
how sorry she was, yes, and something else,
too, which she had just discovered herself
now that he was gone forever.
So the day dragged on, Elizabeth scarcely
knew how. She pleaded headache—which
was certainly no idle excuse—and shut herself up with the three great facts of her life:
that she loved Harry Gaylord with all the
strength of her being, that she had done him
a great wrong, and that he was gone !
In the meantime 362 Nelson Street was the
scene of what might be termed a tragic
comedy. The crape on the door showed that
death had set its seal there, while there was
the coming and going and profusion of
flowers that mark such occasions, yet there
was something in the expression of those who
came out of the house that would have puzzled an observer.
A lady, dressed in black and carrying a
bunch of ferns and roses, ascended the steps
and entered the hall. Strangely enough Mrs.
Gaylord was there, and though she wore deep
back, one could almost imagine that she
smiled. Not noticing her quiet Good morning," Mrs. Morton, the lady thus addressed,
ran to her and, throwing her arms around her,
cried, "Oh! Annie! isn't it awful! poor, poor
Harry!"
Mrs. Gaylord managed to free herself from
the embrace in which she was held and said,
"Mrs. Morton, Harry is not dead; he is alive,
and perfectly well."
"Oh, Annie has lost her mind!" exclaimed
Mrs. Morton burying her face in her handkerchief. "I knew she could never bear the
shock!"
Still bemoaning the sad state of her friend,
Mrs. Morton went into the parlor, where in a
plain black casket lay, not handsome Harry
Gaylord, but an aged man whose wrinkled
face and toil-worn hands showed many years
of combat with the world.
The mystery was easily explained. About

a month before Mr. Gaylord, Harry's father,
had accidentally met the man who years ago
had given him his first start in business, but
who from a series of misfortunes, was at that
time friendless, and in destitute circumstances.
Mr. Gaylord cordially received him into his
home, where, as the paper correctly stated, he
had died suddenly the night preceding the
day of which we write. His name being
Henry Gale, the mistake was not surprising.
Harry had almost lost sight of his last
night's troubles in the novelty of attending
his own funeral, or something very like it.
Someone suggested that he make his appearance upon the scene, and so convince his
friends that he was not dead; but the first
time this was tried one lady fainted and such
a panic followed that Harry saying he would
rather play dead man than spook, discreetly
kept himself out of sight for the remainder of
the day. Mr. and Mrs. Gaylord were overwhelmed with messages of condolence, while
friends and relatives continued to flock in
with their offerings of flowers, and words of
praise for "poor Harry," until with explaining and convincing the members of the Gaylord family were completely worn out.
At last the ludicrous side of the situation
became too much for Harry, and finding himself no longer able to mantain the gravity
which the occasion required, he escaped from
his uninvited visitors and went to the home
of his uncle a few squares away, where, as he
expressed it, he "could have his laugh out in
peace."
With an appreciation of quiet which he had
never known before, Harry was sitting in the
twilight talking over the events of the day
with his uncle and aunt, when there was a
violent ring of the door bell, and in an other
moment Elizabeth Winter rushed in and threw
herself in Mrs. Gaylord's arms.
The lady whom Harry's uncle had married
was a distant relative and warm friend of
Elizabeth, and to her, after a day of intense
agony and self-accusation, the girl had determined to come.
In the half light of the room Elizabeth had
not seen Harry, whose heart thrilled as he
had heard her exclaim.
"Oh, Ethel ! he is dead, and it is all my

THE NEWS-LETTER.

fault ! he was so good and noble and I did
everything to tease and worry him."
Seeing that Elizabeth's nerves were in a
state of dangerously high tension, Ethel Gaylord, with true womanly tact, drew her down
on the sofa beside her, and gently though, at
first very gradually, unraveled for her the
tangled web of circumstances in which hetpoor little heart had been held thro' all that
long dreary day.
As the full meaning of what she had heard
dawned upon her Elizabeth sat perfectly quiet
for a few minutes, and then without raising
her head from Ethel's shoulder said:
"Ethel dear, I know you are telling me the
truth, but I can't make myself believe it until
I really see him."
"Then you shall be convinced in your own
way," Ethel replied, and Elizabeth looked up
to find Harry standing before her with outstretched hands. Not a word passed between
the two, but their long warm hand clasp left
no need of words.
A short time later Elizabeth Winter again
stood upon the door step of her own home,
watching the retreating figure of Harry Gaylord as she had done twenty-four hours before.
This time, however, he looked back several
times before he disappeared from view, and
smiled as he saw the white-robed girl still
standing there. And again Elizabeth recalled
the look in Harry's brown eyes as he bade her
good-night, but this time it was full of unspeakable happiness that the very memory
seemed to vibrate within her heart, and blending with the joy that dwelt there made
sweetest music for her all the night.—M.E.H.

A TOUCH OF NATURE.
The editor sat in his big office chair,
The waste-basket sat on the floor;
The one with a sense of importance was filled,
The other with papers galore.
The papers—if ignorance leads you to doubt,
That ignorance never proclaim—
Resented their treatment, and highly incensed,
Declared that 'twas really a shame.
They rattled and rustled at such a wild rate,
That the editor rose from his chair,
And lowered a window; the noise, he inferred,
Was cause by a current of air.
That one touch of nature the whole world
makes kin
Has by sages and saints been found true,
And here events proved that the same rule
applies,
To worlds and waste-baskets too.
These papers, together in such a sad plight,
Let their anger to sympathy sink;
Each quelled its own rage, and in true
Christian way,
Began of its neighbor to think.
A dear little maiden's effusion on "Spring"
And a rural swain's heart-broken lay
Soon found that their pages had gotten mixed
In a most unaccountable way.

Here are some samples of a modern advertisement for new musical compositions:
"Come Where My Love Lies Dreaming"
(with illuminated cover.)
"Trust Her Not" (for so cents.)
"I Would Not Live Always" (without
accompaniment.)
"See. the Conquering Hero Comes" (with
full orchestra.)
"Whe the Sun Shall Set No More" (in C).
"The Tale of the Swordfish" (with many
scales.)
"After the Ball" (for second base.)
"Home, Sweet Home" (in A flat.)
—Exchange.

A bachelor's ode on "The Sorrows of Life"
And a spinster's sad lines upon "Time"
Discovered themselves to be strangely alike,
In substance and meter and rhyme.
"Good Cooking" and Hygeine,quite naturally
met—
Then, when each had a partner obtained,
All cheerfully chatted, forgotting their ire,
And content in the waste-basket reigned.
M. E. H.

CUPIDS MISHAP.
Cupid one day
In battle's array
Went forth to conquer girls' hearts;
But, sad to declare,
He did not beware
Their flatteries fair,
And, by aim misapplied
He was struck in the side
And wounded, himself, by his darts!
For love is perverse,
And what is much worse,
Is doubtful, perplexing, and blind;
It aims in the dark,
Seldom hitting its mark.
Like the fleet soaring lark
In life's morn it doth sing
As it flits on the wing,
But at night in a hush is reclined.
—H. F. G.

JOKES.
Little Margery was giving her kitty a lesson
in catechism.
"Kitty," she began, "who made you ?
Now, you must say 'God'." Then, struck
by another thought, she added sympathetically, "Kitty, didn't it hurt when God stuck
all those feathers in you ?"

Charlie—"Mama, all the other boys in my
class were kept in to-day for throwing stones
at a poor lame dog."
Mama—"I am glad that my boy took no
part in such cruel sport."
Charlie—"Oh, I wasn't even with the
crowd; I was back of the school-house, trying
to catch a toad-frog to put in teacher's desk."

Little five-year-old Harry was spending
the day with his Aunt, Dinner was somewhat late, and the child began to grow restless.
"Auntie," he said, at length, "does God
know everything ?"
His aunt answered in the affirmative.
"Every little thing ?" he persisted.
"Yes, every little thing," was the reply.
"Well, then," said the little boy, "God
knows I'm hungry, don't He ?"

EDITORIAL.
If

0;9

HE NEWS-LETTER wishes to express its thanks to the Board of
Editors of the 1907 Hullabaloo for the kind loan of the photographs
which are published in this issue. In regard to the individual plates
the NEWS-LETTER regrets the impossibility of presenting the photographs of every member of the Senior class; and has, therefore,
picked out several men, not necessarily better than the other members
of their class, but representative of the class. Hopkins must realize
how much they loose by the graduation of the class of 1907. As
undergraduates they have done much for the University; as gradv is le
uates, "Medies" and Alumni they are able, if they will, to do even
more. Good luck to them, every one!

4R.

:$:$:

ITH this issue the eleventh volume of the NEWS-LETTER is brought
to an end. The first nUmber of the volume was published while
Little Ross street was echoing with the squeals of the infant class of
1909; this final number will come into the hands of its readers after
the new freshmen have received their first lessons in the art of conducting themselves properly.
The NEWS-LETTER has partaken in the joys and sorrows of the
past year at Hopkins. The not over-brilliant showing made by the
Football team last fall has been more than offset by the splendid work
of the Lacrosse team this spring, the defeat (which by the way was
nearly a victory) at the Annapolis meet was atoned for by the victory over Virginia. And so
it is always in life. Even the NEWS-LETTER has had like experiences—but in spite of the
mental defeats of the Board of Editors when vainly trying to think up a new joke, we too
have our victories—of which the promise of another successful year next winter is a notable
one.

(.-If/eI. Poe.)

Dearest, thy voice comes to me,
To-night as to a wave-beat shore,
The song of sailors, far at sea,
Echoes the stormy ocean o'er,
And then is heard no more.

4

To hold that little hand of thine,
Fain would I now, to feel that hand,
All powerful though held in mine,
Yet holding me by stronger band
Than ever moored a ship to land.
Dearest I see thy face to-night,
So pure, so fragrant, and so fair;•
Before me in the dimness bright,
As bright as truth, I see thee there,
Yet gaze but on the vacant air!
If in my visions thus thou art,
Small wonder then, that I love thee;
The shadow is a tiny part
Of thy real beauty, and to see
Thyself is heaven of heaven to me!

HE CHA:\I PION LACROSSE TFAM OF 190-

CUPID'S STRATAGEM.

5

For once in her life Elizabeth Winter was

oily the memory of the suffering on his face,

young people talking and laughing merrily as me; she shall never grieve beeause I suffer,
since she cannot love me." He bade her
they passed.
good-night somewhat abruptly, and, little
Elizabeth turned mechanically, went into
knowing how in one lingering look he had
the house, locked the door behind her, and,
told the girl his whole heart's story, he left her
going to her own room, threw herself into a
stunned and awed by the strength of the feelchair, and proceeded to think matters over
ing which she had read in that one moment.
calmly, or, at lesst quietly.
It was nearly daylight before Elizabeth
She had known Harry Gaylord for more found relief in sleep. The thought that she
than two years, and, tho' the friendship which could atone for her folly when she next saw
had existed between them from the beginning Harry seemed to bring little comfort. Next
of their acquaintance had been very pleasant time seemed so vague and far-off. When she
and matter-of-fact, her woman's intuition had awoke, after a few hours of troubled sleep, it
told her sometime since that she was becom- was with a dull sense of present or impending
ing more to him than could be expressed in calamity. She dressed and went down to the
the word "friend." She did not question her breakfast-room, but none of the other memown heart, but was quite content to let mat- bers of the family had yet made their appearters rest as they were. She acknowledged the ance. The morning paper lay beside her
congeniality between him and herself and father's plate, and, as she picked it up and
recognized the full value of the sterling glanced carelessly over it, her eye fell upon
qualities which he possessed, but her heart the following notice: Died—"Of heart-failure,
was in no hurry to own the master, and she on July 20th, Henry Gaylord at 362 Nelson
chatted and danced with other men, often Street."
finding compensation for the lack of pleasure
Putting the paper back in its place she
which she found in their company in her returned to her room, hardly comprehending
mischievous enjoyment of the look of annoy- the meaning of what she had read. There
ance on Harry's face.
could be no doubt about it—"Henry Gaylord
On the evening in question there had been at 362 Nelson Street;" his name was probably
something in Harry Gaylord's manner when Henry, altho she had always kuown him as

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Harry, and the address given was certainly
his. Then like a flash she remembered how,
on the preceding evening, he had suddenly
turned pale and stopped in the middle of a
sentence, but had assured her that it was only
a sharp pain around the heart which the
Doctor said was nothing serious—and now,
he was gone ! gone, before she could tell him
how sorry she was, yes, and something else,
too, which she had just discovered herself
now that he was gone forever.
So the day dragged on, Elizabeth scarcely
knew how. She pleaded headache—which
was certainly no idle excuse—and shut herself up with the three great facts of her life:
that she loved Harry Gaylord with all the
strength of her being, that she had done him
a great wrong, and that he was gone !
In the meantime 362 Nelson Street was the
scene of what might be termed a tragic
comedy. The crape on the door showed that
death had set its seal there, while there was
the coming and going and profusion of
flowers that mark such occasions, yet there
was something in the expression of those who
came out of the house that would have puzzled an observer.
A lady, dressed in black and carrying a
bunch of ferns and roses, ascended the steps
and entered the hall. Strangely enough Mrs.
Gaylord was there, and though she wore deep
back, one could almost imagine that she
smiled. Not noticing her quiet Good morning," Mrs. Morton, the lady thus addressed,
ran to her and, throwing her arms around her,
cried, "Oh! Annie! isn't it awful! poor, poor
Harry!"
Mrs. Gaylord managed to free herself from
the embrace in which she was held and said,
"Mrs. Morton, Harry is not dead; he is alive,
and perfectly well."
"Oh, Annie has lost her mind!" exclaimed
Mrs. Morton burying her face in her handkerchief. "I knew she could never bear the
shock!"
Still bemoaning the sad state of her friend,
Mrs. Morton went into the parlor, where in a
plain black casket lay, not handsome Harry
Gaylord, but an aged man whose wrinkled
face and toil-worn hands showed many years
of combat with the world.
The mystery was easily explained. About

a month before Mr. Gaylord, Harry's father,
had accidentally met the man who years ago
had given him his first start in business, but
who from a series of misfortunes, was at that
time friendless, and in destitute circumstances.
Mr. Gaylord cordially received him into his
home, where, as the paper correctly stated, he
had died suddenly the night preceding the
day of which we write. His name being
Henry Gale, the mistake was not surprising.
Harry had almost lost sight of his last
night's troubles in the novelty of attending
his own funeral, or something very like it.
Someone suggested that he make his appearance upon the scene, and so convince his
friends that he was not dead; but the first
time this was tried one lady fainted and such
a panic followed that Harry saying he would
rather play dead man than spook, discreetly
kept himself out of sight for the remainder of
the day. Mr. and Mrs. Gaylord were overwhelmed with messages of condolence, while
friends and relatives continued to flock in
with their offerings of flowers, and words of
praise for "poor Harry," until with explaining and convincing the members of the Gaylord family were completely worn out.
At last the ludicrous side of the situation
became too much for Harry, and finding himself no longer able to mantain the gravity
which the occasion required, he escaped from
his uninvited visitors and went to the home
of his uncle a few squares away, where, as he
expressed it, he "could have his laugh out in
peace."
With an appreciation of quiet which he had
never known before, Harry was sitting in the
twilight talking over the events of the day
with his uncle and aunt, when there was a
violent ring of the door bell, and in an other
moment Elizabeth Winter rushed in and threw
herself in Mrs. Gaylord's arms.
The lady whom Harry's uncle had married
was a distant relative and warm friend of
Elizabeth, and to her, after a day of intense
agony and self-accusation, the girl had determined to come.
In the half light of the room Elizabeth had
not seen Harry, whose heart thrilled as he
had heard her exclaim.
"Oh, Ethel ! he is dead, and it is all my

THE NEWS-LETTER.

fault ! he was so good and noble and I did
everything to tease and worry him."
Seeing that Elizabeth's nerves were in a
state of dangerously high tension, Ethel Gaylord, with true womanly tact, drew her down
on the sofa beside her, and gently though, at
first very gradually, unraveled for her the
tangled web of circumstances in which hetpoor little heart had been held thro' all that
long dreary day.
As the full meaning of what she had heard
dawned upon her Elizabeth sat perfectly quiet
for a few minutes, and then without raising
her head from Ethel's shoulder said:
"Ethel dear, I know you are telling me the
truth, but I can't make myself believe it until
I really see him."
"Then you shall be convinced in your own
way," Ethel replied, and Elizabeth looked up
to find Harry standing before her with outstretched hands. Not a word passed between
the two, but their long warm hand clasp left
no need of words.
A short time later Elizabeth Winter again
stood upon the door step of her own home,
watching the retreating figure of Harry Gaylord as she had done twenty-four hours before.
This time, however, he looked back several
times before he disappeared from view, and
smiled as he saw the white-robed girl still
standing there. And again Elizabeth recalled
the look in Harry's brown eyes as he bade her
good-night, but this time it was full of unspeakable happiness that the very memory
seemed to vibrate within her heart, and blending with the joy that dwelt there made
sweetest music for her all the night.—M.E.H.

A TOUCH OF NATURE.
The editor sat in his big office chair,
The waste-basket sat on the floor;
The one with a sense of importance was filled,
The other with papers galore.
The papers—if ignorance leads you to doubt,
That ignorance never proclaim—
Resented their treatment, and highly incensed,
Declared that 'twas really a shame.
They rattled and rustled at such a wild rate,
That the editor rose from his chair,
And lowered a window; the noise, he inferred,
Was cause by a current of air.
That one touch of nature the whole world
makes kin
Has by sages and saints been found true,
And here events proved that the same rule
applies,
To worlds and waste-baskets too.
These papers, together in such a sad plight,
Let their anger to sympathy sink;
Each quelled its own rage, and in true
Christian way,
Began of its neighbor to think.
A dear little maiden's effusion on "Spring"
And a rural swain's heart-broken lay
Soon found that their pages had gotten mixed
In a most unaccountable way.

Here are some samples of a modern advertisement for new musical compositions:
"Come Where My Love Lies Dreaming"
(with illuminated cover.)
"Trust Her Not" (for so cents.)
"I Would Not Live Always" (without
accompaniment.)
"See. the Conquering Hero Comes" (with
full orchestra.)
"Whe the Sun Shall Set No More" (in C).
"The Tale of the Swordfish" (with many
scales.)
"After the Ball" (for second base.)
"Home, Sweet Home" (in A flat.)
—Exchange.

A bachelor's ode on "The Sorrows of Life"
And a spinster's sad lines upon "Time"
Discovered themselves to be strangely alike,
In substance and meter and rhyme.
"Good Cooking" and Hygeine,quite naturally
met—
Then, when each had a partner obtained,
All cheerfully chatted, forgotting their ire,
And content in the waste-basket reigned.
M. E. H.

up a motion that you can make, and make it.
Do not attempt to bite yourself. Likewise do
NOT attempt to make a motion to adjourn
until you have read this paper through at
least once. By no means attempt to leave
the room until you have spent at least five
minutes in contemplation; your number has
been taken and you will be stopped at the
door. Fold your yaper neatly, writing ths
date, hour, size of hat, father's avocation,
name of subject (this is important), and name,
so that your instructor will know what and
wherefore.

(Successor to HOLZAPPRIi & BEIM)

CUPIDS MISHAP.
Cupid one day
In battle's array
Went forth to conquer girls' hearts;
But, sad to declare,
He did not beware
Their flatteries fair,
And, by aim misapplied
He was struck in the side
And wounded, himself, by his darts!
For love is perverse,
And what is much worse,
Is doubtful, perplexing, and blind;
It aims in the dark,
Seldom hitting its mark.
Like the fleet soaring lark
In life's morn it doth sing
As it flits on the wing,
But at night in a hush is reclined.
—H. F. G.

ARTISTIC PHOTOGRAPHS

JOKES.
Little Margery was giving her kitty a lesson
in catechism.
"Kitty," she began, "who made you ?
Now, you must say 'God'." Then, struck
by another thought, she added sympathetically, "Kitty, didn't it hurt when God stuck
all those feathers in you ?"

Charlie—"Mama, all the other boys in my
class were kept in to-day for throwing stones
at a poor lame dog."
Mama—"I am glad that my boy took no
part in such cruel sport."
Charlie—"Oh, I wasn't even with the
crowd; I was back of the school-house, trying
to catch a toad-frog to put in teacher's desk."

Little five-year-old Harry was spending
the day with his Aunt, Dinner was somewhat late, and the child began to grow restless.
"Auntie," he said, at length, "does God
know everything ?"
His aunt answered in the affirmative.
"Every little thing ?" he persisted.
"Yes, every little thing," was the reply.
"Well, then," said the little boy, "God
knows I'm hungry, don't He ?"
